Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Electrical detection of individual biomolecular interactions and machine learning-assisted simulations: from single-molecule biophysics to the RISC complex

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: This EAGER award will fund the development of a novel nanotechnology based method to measure biomolecular interactions between two or more proteins or between proteins and nucleic acids. These types of interactions are interactions are at the heart of most biochemical processes. The new method developed in this work could be applied to numerous biological problems, paving the way to a whole new body of knowledge in biophysics. This research will enhance the training and education possibilities of the next generations of biochemists, scientists, and engineers in general, and improve the workforce by training them to use the modern machine-learning tools. This project will also promote the STEM participation of women and underrepresented minorities.<br/><br/>The proposed research will use novel nanotechnology methods to measure the electrical conductivities related to biomolecular interactions. The overall objective for this project is the electronic quantification of biomolecular interactions, including both thermodynamic and kinetic information as a proof-of-concept. The central hypothesis of this approach is that electronic fingerprints from biomolecular interactions contain thermodynamic and kinetic information that correlate with the biological function of this complex. The direct observation of the dynamics of interaction between individual biomolecules will allow a development of a complete biophysical picture underlying the biochemistry of biomolecular interactions. The research offers radically different interdisciplinary approach based on expertise in single-molecule biophysics and biochemistry in the experimental front, and extensive theory-driven computer simulations experience using Molecular Dynamics and Quantum Chemistry on the computational side.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biomolecular interactions between nucleic acids and proteins are at the heart of most biological processes. The overall objective of this project is the electrical quantification of biomolecular interactions in RNA-proteins biomolecular complexes at the individual complex level (e.g., the RISC complex). The central hypothesis of this approach is that electrical fingerprints from biomolecular interactions contain thermodynamic and kinetic information that correlates with biophysical properties and the biological function of the complexes. We use novel nanotechnology methods (the STM-based molecular junctions, STMBJ) to measure the electrical conductivity of these biomolecular interactions. With this EAGER project, we have developed the methods to measure the electrical fingerprint of biomolecular interactions using STMBJ. As a final report:

 

1. We have successfully adapted BioMolecular Electronics methods (measurement of electrical conductance through individual biomolecules) for the measurement of RNA-protein interactions. 

2. We started with the electrical measurement of individual doublestranded (ds)RNA molecules. Comparing dsRNA with DNA:RNA hybrids, we concluded that the electrical signal is similar, but shows more dispersion in dsRNA, showing a higher flexibility for RNA vs DNA. With the aid of molecular dynamics simulations, we rationalized this fact and correlated it with the biomolecular biological function. These results resulted in a high-impact peer-reviewed publication.

3. We also measured the electrical fingerprints of single-stranded (ss) RNA. Only short sequences capable of base stacking support electrical conduction and result in an electrical fingerprint. This gives further clues to understand the mechanism for molecular conduction in these biomolecules at these low energies. The results are part of a manuscript currently in revision.

4. As the last missing piece to measure the RISC complex, we measured the protein Argonaute with our STMBJ setup, obtaining no electrical signal. This indicates that argonaute cannot bind to the electrodes and will not result in any electrical fingerprint.

5. Finally, we conducted proof-of-concept experiments showing electrical signals of RNA-Ago interactions on a population of complexes using electrochemistry and in individual complexes with biomolecular electronics. These results are part of two manuscripts in preparation. Briefly, in both cases, the electrical signals show marked differences when the RNA-Ago interaction occurs. 

6. Besides the articles published, in revision, and currently in preparation, these results were communicated in multiple major conferences, including:  The American Chemical Society National Meetings 2020, 2021, 2022

Regional Meeting from the ACS such us the NERM 2021 and 2022

The Materials Research Society Meetings 2020, 2021, and 2022.

 

For Broader Impacts:

-The measurements on RNA electrical conductance, resulted in unexpected applications, such as biosensors (submitted to ACS Sustainable Chem and Eng) for the early screening of cancer biomarkers (in press Sci Rep 2023) or COVID-19 (in press Biosensors and Bioelectronics 2023).

- In addition to these fundamental and derived results above, this EAGER project provided training for several graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. Some of them were members of underrepresented minorities in STEM and participated in the research and have co-authored research products in the form of conference contributions or articles.
